tit.cmt: タイトルなので大文字にしました。括弧説明は削除しました。

sen.j: 注連縄（しめなわ）は、神道における神祭具で、宗教上の意味を持つ紙垂（しで）をつけたロープをさす。
sen.e: The Shimenawa rope (sacred straw rope) is a ceremonial article of significance in Shinto and, the rope has religious meaning when adorned with shide (zig-zag shaped paper tallismen.
The Shimenawa rope (sacred straw rope) is a ceremonial article of significance in Shinto and, the rope has religious meaning when adorned with shide (zig-zag shaped paper tallismen.
The Shimenawa rope (sacred straw rope) is a ceremonial article of significance in Shinto and, the rope has religious meaning when adorned with shide (zigzag shaped paper talisman).
sen.cmt: zigzag、talismanスペル訂正しました。)補足しました。

sen.j: 標縄・七五三縄とも表記する。
sen.e: Shimenawa ropes are also called `7-5-3 ropes`.
Shimenawa ropes are also called `7-5-3 ropes`.
Shimenawa ropes are also called '7-5-3 ropes.'
sen.cmt: 全角の’を半角にしました。

sen.j: 現在の神社神道では「社（やしろ）」・神域と現世を隔てる結界の役割を意味する。
sen.e: In current day shrine based Shinto, the rope takes the role of and demarcating the shrine and precincts from the every-day world.
In current day shrine based Shinto, the rope takes the role of and demarcating the shrine and precincts from the every-day world.
In current day shrine based Shinto, the rope takes the role of and demarcating the shrine and precincts from the every-day world.

sen.j: また神社の周り、あるいは神体を縄で囲う。
sen.e: Also, the surrounds of the temple and places where deities reside are enclosed by Shimenawa ropes.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文例外対処
sen.e: Also, the surrounds of the temple and places where deities reside are enclosed by Shimenawa ropes.
Also, the surrounds of the shrine and places where deities reside are enclosed by Shimenawa ropes.

sen.j: その中を神域としたり、厄や禍を祓う結界の意味もある。
sen.e: Consecrated ground falls within these confines and, the ropes are a spiritual cleansing barrier warding off misfortune and evil.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文例外対処
sen.e: Consecrated ground falls within these confines and, the ropes are a spiritual cleansing barrier warding off misfortune and evil.
Consecrated ground falls within these confines and, the ropes are a spiritual cleansing barrier warding off misfortune and evil.

sen.j: 御霊代（みたましろ）・依り代（よりしろ）として神がここに宿っているという印ともされる。
sen.e: As Mitamashiro (revered deity spirits and objects) and Yorishiro (objects representing divine spirits) the ropes convey a sense that the gods can reside in that location.
As Mitamashiro (revered deity spirits and objects) and Yorishiro (objects representing divine spirits) the ropes convey a sense that the gods can reside in that location.
As Mitamashiro (revered deity spirits and objects) and Yorishiro (objects representing divine spirits) the ropes convey a sense that the gods can reside in that location.

sen.j: 古神道においては、神域はすなわち常世（とこよ）であり、俗世は現実社会を意味する現世（うつしよ）である。
sen.e: In Shinto of ancient times, consecrated ground was eternal, whereas this world was a transient representation of the real world.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文例外対処
sen.e: In Shinto of ancient times, consecrated ground was eternal, whereas this world was a transient representation of the real world.
In Shinto of ancient times, consecrated ground was eternal, whereas this world was a transient representation of the real world.
sen.cmt: スペース削除しました。

sen.j: 注連縄はこの二つの世界の端境や結界を表し、場所によっては禁足地の印ともなっている。
sen.e: The Shimenawa rope represented the border and barrier between those two worlds and in some situations signified a prohibited area.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文例外対処
sen.e: The Shimenawa rope represented the border and barrier between those two worlds and in some situations signified a prohibited area.
The Shimenawa rope represented the border and barrier between those two worlds and in some situations signified a prohibited area.

sen.j: 御旅所にも張られ、海の岩礁の内、奇岩とされるものなどにも注連縄が張られる。
sen.e: Shimenawa ropes are hung around: places where portable festival shrines are stored, reef outcrops in the sea, unusually shaped rock formations etc.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文例外対処
sen.e: Shimenawa ropes are hung around: places where portable festival shrines are stored, reef outcrops in the sea, unusually shaped rock formations etc.
Shimenawa ropes are hung around: places where portable festival shrines are stored, reef outcrops in the sea, unusually shaped rock formations etc.

tit.j: よく知られるものとして夫婦岩がある。
tit.e: Meotoiwa (pairs of rock outcrops near each other) are well know examples of this practice.
tit.cmt: 一原文一訳文例外対処
tit.e: Meotoiwa (pairs of rock outcrops near each other) are well know examples of this practice.
Meotoiwa (pairs of rock outcrops near each other) are well know examples of this practice.

sen.j: また日本の正月、家々の門、玄関、出入り口などに飾る注連飾がある。
sen.e: Also at new year time in Japan, Shimenawa ropes are hung on the gates of households, porch landings, entrances and exits.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文例外対処
sen.e: Also at new year time in Japan, Shimenawa ropes are hung on the gates of households, porch landings, entrances and exits.
Also at new year time in Japan, Shimenawa ropes are hung on the gates of households, porch landings, entrances and exits.

sen.j: これも注連縄の一形態であり、厄や禍を祓う結界の意味を持つ。
sen.e: These form one type of Shimenawa rope which symbolizes a barrier warding off evil and misfortune.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文例外対処
sen.e: These form one type of Shimenawa rope which symbolizes a barrier warding off evil and misfortune.
These form one type of Shimenawa rope which symbolizes a barrier warding off evil and misfortune.

sen.j: 大相撲の最高位の大関の中で、選ばれた特別な力士だけが、締めることを許される横綱も注連縄である。
sen.e: From among the Ozeki (second highest rank) of Sumo wrestling, only particular select wrestlers are to be permitted to tie the Shimenawa rope that goes around the waist of the Yokozuna (grand champion).
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文例外対処
sen.e: From among the Ozeki (second highest rank) of Sumo wrestling, only particular select wrestlers are to be permitted to tie the Shimenawa rope that goes around the waist of the Yokozuna (grand champion).

From among the Ozeki (second highest rank) of Sumo wrestling, only particular select wrestlers are to be permitted to tie the Shimenawa rope that goes around the waist of the Yokozuna (grand champion).

sen.j: 現在でも雷（稲妻）が落ちた場所で特に水田などでは青竹で囲い、注連縄をはって、五穀豊穣を願う慣わしが各地で行われている。
sen.e: Currently, places where lightning strikes (in particular when in rice paddies) are cordoned off with green bamboo from which a Shimenawa rope is then strung around. It is the custom in various regions of Japan to then pray for a bountiful crop.

Currently, places where lightning strikes (in particular when in rice paddies) are cordoned off with green bamboo from which a Shimenawa rope is then strung around. It is the custom in various regions of Japan to then pray for a bountiful crop.

Currently, places where lightning strikes (in particular when in rice paddies) are cordoned off with green bamboo from which a Shimenawa rope is then strung around. It is the custom in various regions of Japan to then pray for a bountiful crop.

sen.j: 起源
sen.e: Origins
Origins
Origins

sen.j: 日本神話
sen.e: Japanese Mythology
Japanese Mythology
Japanese Mythology

sen.j: 天照大神が天岩戸から引き出された際、二度と天岩戸に入れないよう太玉命が注連縄（「尻久米縄」）で戸を塞いだのが起源とされる。
sen.e: The Shimenawa myth has its origins from when Amaterasu Omikami (the Sun Goddess) was removed from the Ama no iwato (Cave of heaven), Ame no Futotama no Mikoto (one of the gods in Japanese mythology) strung a Shimenawa across the cave entrance to prevent the cave being entered again.

The Shimenawa myth has its origins from when Amaterasu Omikami (the Sun Goddess) was removed from the Ama no iwato (Cave of heaven), Ame no Futotama no Mikoto (one of the gods in Japanese mythology) strung a Shimenawa across the cave entrance to prevent the cave being entered again.

The Shimenawa myth has its origins from when Amaterasu Omikami (the Sun Goddess) was removed from the Ama no iwato (Cave of heaven), Ame no Futotama no Mikoto (one of the gods in Japanese mythology) strung a Shimenawa across the cave entrance to prevent the cave being entered again.

sen.j: 稲作信仰
sen.e: Beliefs related to the rice harvest
Beliefs related to the rice harvest
Beliefs related to the rice harvest

sen.j: 稲作信仰は神道の根幹をなす一つである。
sen.e: Beliefs related to the rice harvest are a fundamental thread running through Shinto.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文例外対処
sen.e: Beliefs related to the rice harvest are a fundamental thread running through Shinto.
Beliefs related to the rice harvest are a fundamental thread running through Shinto.

tit.j: 自然崇拝でもある古神道にも古い時代から存在する。
tit.e: Worship of nature has existed since ancient times in ancient forms of Shinto.
tit.cmt: 一原文一訳文例外対処
tit.e: Worship of nature has existed since ancient times in ancient forms of Shinto.
Worship of nature has existed since ancient times in ancient forms of Shinto.

sen.j: ロープの材料は刈り取って干したイネ藁、又は麻である。
sen.e: Ropes were made of either hemp or rice straw that had been harvested and dried.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文例外対処
sen.e: Ropes were made of either hemp or rice straw that had been harvested and dried.
Ropes were made of either hemp or rice straw that had been harvested and dried.

sen.j: 稲作文化とかかわりの深い風習だと考えられる。
sen.e: Customs and traditions that accompany the rice harvest culture are thought to run deep.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文例外対処
sen.e: Customs and traditions that accompany the rice harvest culture are thought to run deep.
Customs and traditions that accompany the rice harvest culture are thought to run deep.

sen.j: 古神道
sen.e: Ancient Shinto
Ancient Shinto
Ancient Shinto

sen.j: 神が鎮座（神留・かんづま）する山や森を神奈備といい信仰した。
sen.e: Religious beliefs that include beliefs that deities are enshrined in mountains and forests are called `kannabi`.
Religious beliefs that include beliefs that deities are enshrined in mountains and forests are called `kannabi`.
Religious beliefs that include beliefs that deities are enshrined in mountains and forests are called 'kannabi.'
sen.cmt: 全角の’を半角に訂正します。

sen.j: 後に森や木々の神籬（ひもろぎ）や山や岩の磐座（いわくら）ともいわれたが、神の宿る降りる場所や神体として祀られ、その証として注連縄がまかれた。
sen.e: Later on, mention was made of primitive shrines in forests and woods as well as on rock formations and mountains but, places where the deities ascended form the heavens and rested and places where deities resided and were worshiped were identified by being roped off with a Shimenawa.

Later on, mention was made of primitive shrines in forests and woods as well as on rock formations and mountains but, places where the deities ascended form the heavens and rested and places where deities resided and were worshiped were identified by being roped off with a Shimenawa.

Later on, mention was made of primitive shrines in forests and woods as well as on rock formations and mountains but, places where the deities ascended form the heavens and rested and places where deities resided and were worshiped were identified by being roped off with a Shimenawa.

sen.j: 注連縄・注連飾りには、大根締め、ゴボウ締め、輪飾りなど色々な種類の形式がある。
sen.e: Shimenawa come in many various forms: standard Shimenawa, ornamented Shimenawa, daikon (giant radish) Shimenawa, burdock Shimenawa, ring Shimenawa etc.
Shimenawa come in many various forms: standard Shimenawa, ornamented Shimenawa, daikon (giant radish) Shimenawa, burdock Shimenawa, ring Shimenawa etc.
Shimenawa come in many various forms: standard Shimenawa, ornamented Shimenawa, daikon (giant radish) Shimenawa, burdock Shimenawa, ring Shimenawa etc.

sen.j: 大根締めは両端がつぼまり、ゴボウ締めは片側のみが細い。
sen.e: Daikon (giant radish) Shimenawa taper at both ends and, burdock Shimenawa are thinner at just one end.
Daikon (giant radish) Shimenawa taper at both ends and, burdock Shimenawa are thinner at just one end.
Daikon (giant radish) Shimenawa taper at both ends and, burdock Shimenawa are thinner at just one end.

sen.j: 日本以外の宗教的な縄
sen.e: Religious use of ropes other than in Japan.
Religious use of ropes other than in Japan.
Religious use of ropes other than in Japan.

sen.j: 朝鮮中南部にもクムジュル（禁縄）というよく似た風習がある。
sen.e: In the central southern part of Korea a similar custom called `kumchul`(금줄/禁縄) exists.
In the central southern part of Korea a similar custom called `kumchul`(금줄/禁縄) exists.
In the central southern part of Korea a similar custom called 'kumchul' (금줄/禁縄) exists.
sen.cmt: 全角の’を半角に訂正します。

sen.j: 注連飾り
sen.e: Displaying Shimenawa
Displaying Shimenawa
Displaying Shimenawa

sen.j: 正月に迎える年神を祀る依り代として飾る。
sen.e: Forms representing the gods are displayed for worship in the new year.
Forms representing the gods are displayed for worship in the new year.
Forms representing the gods are displayed for worship in the new year.

sen.j: 玄関に飾るものを玉飾りと呼び、台所やトイレなどに飾る略したものを輪じめと呼ぶ。
sen.e: Those displayed in the entranceways of homes are called `tamakazari`, those on display in the kitchen and bathrooms of a home are somewhat simpler and called `rinjime` (hoop ropes).
Those displayed in the entranceways of homes are called `tamakazari`, those on display in the kitchen and bathrooms of a home are somewhat simpler and called `rinjime` (hoop ropes).
Those displayed in the entranceways of homes are called 'tamakazari,' those on display in the kitchen and bathrooms of a home are somewhat simpler and called 'wajime' (hoop ropes).
sen.cmt: 全角の’を半角に訂正します。rinjimeはwajimeに訂正しました。

sen.j: 玉飾りには、地域によって異なるが、縁起物である紙垂、ダイダイ、ウラジロなどが同時に飾られる。
sen.e: Tamakazari differ from region to region in Japan however, zig-zag paper tallismen, bitter orange (Citrus aurantium) and fern with white-backed leaves (Sorbus japonica) are often used together in decorations.

Tamakazari differ from region to region in Japan however, zig-zag paper tallismen, bitter orange (Citrus aurantium) and fern with white-backed leaves (Sorbus japonica) are often used together in decorations.

Tamakazari differ from region to region in Japan however, zigzag paper talisman, bitter orange (Citrus aurantium) and fern with white-backed leaves (Sorbus japonica) are often used together in decorations.

sen.j: 飾る時期
sen.e: Timing of Decorations
Timing of Decorations
Timing of Decorations

sen.j: 飾り始める日は松飾りの飾る期間と同じ扱いで良いが、地域によって風習は異なる。
sen.e: The first day for Shimenawa decorations is ideally thought to be the same as when New Year's pine decorations are put on show however, customs differ from region to region.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文例外対処
sen.e: The first day for Shimenawa decorations is ideally thought to be the same as when New Year's pine decorations are put on show however, customs differ from region to region.
The first day for Shimenawa decorations is ideally thought to be the same as when New Year's pine decorations are put on show however, customs differ from region to region.

sen.j: 現在ではクリスマス後から28日までに飾る事が一般的である。
sen.e: Ｃurrently， decorations are commonly put on display after Christmas and up until the 28th.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文例外対処
sen.e: Ｃurrently， decorations are commonly put on display after Christmas and up until the 28th.
Currently, decorations are commonly put on display after Christmas and up until the 28th.

sen.j: 29日と31日に飾る事は縁起が悪い事とされる。
sen.e: Putting up decorations between the 29th and 31st is considered bad luck.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文例外対処
sen.e: Putting up decorations between the 29th and 31st is considered bad luck.
Putting up decorations between the 29th and 31st is considered bad luck.

sen.j: 31日に飾る事を一夜飾りといい、迎え入れる神様に失礼であるとされる。
sen.e: Decorations put up on the 31st are only up for one night which is considered rude to the incoming gods.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文例外対処
sen.e: Decorations put up on the 31st are only up for one night which is considered rude to the incoming gods.
Decorations put up on the 31st are only up for one night which is considered rude to the incoming gods.

sen.j: 飾りを取り外す日も地域によって風習が異なる。
sen.e: The custom of the day decorations are taken down also differs from region to region.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文例外対処
sen.e: The custom of the day decorations are taken down also differs from region to region.
The custom of the day decorations are taken down also differs from region to region.

sen.j: 1月7日に七草がゆを食べた後、若しくは15日の小正月の後に取り外すとされる。
sen.e: On January 7, after 7 herb congee has been eaten or, the after the 15th (the minor/former new year) is when decorations are removed.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文例外対処
sen.e: On January 7, after 7 herb congee has been eaten or, the after the 15th (the minor/former new year) is when decorations are removed.
On January 7, after 7 herb congee has been eaten or, the after the 15th (the minor/former new year) is when decorations are removed.
